g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: To use the file I/O examples, you must have read-write access to the default directory, which is the directory from which G2 was launched.

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: files will appear here V V V

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: test-directory-exists() exists-p: truth-value; begin exists-p = call g2-directory-exists(directory-to-access); if exists-p then change the text of directory-message to "@"[directory-to-access]@" exists and is a directory" else change the text of directory-message to "@"[directory-to-access]@" does not exist or is not a directory" end

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: Example Uses of the System Procedures

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: clear
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: change the text of every message upon this workspace to ""

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: Examples of Extracting Text from Filestrings
Examples of Extracting Text from Filestrings

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: clear
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: change the text of every message upon this workspace to ""

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: Examples of Extracting Text from Filestrings

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: bytes to decompose into a float:

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: test-bytes-to-float() = () result: float; begin result = call g2-bytes-to-float (byte-to-compose-into-float-1, byte-to-compose-into-float-2, byte-to-compose-into-float-3, byte-to-compose-into-float-4, byte-to-compose-into-float-5, byte-to-compose-into-float-6, byte-to-compose-into-float-7, byte-to-compose-into-float-8); change the text of float-composed-of-bytes to "[result]"; end

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: Examples of File Reading and Writing - Floats
Examples of File Reading and Writing

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: close
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: delete the g2-stream upon this workspace

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: test-file-names-are-identical() identical-p: truth-value; begin identical-p = call g2-file-names-are-identical(file-with-attributes, possibly-identical-file); if identical-p then change the text of characteristics-message to "@"[file-with-attributes]@" and @"[possibly-identical-file]@" are identically named" else change the text of characteristics-message to "@"[file-with-attributes]@" and @"[possibly-identical-file]@" are differently named" end

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: get position
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: in order change the text of get-position-message to "" and start test-get-position(the g2-stream upon this workspace)

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: jh, 11/29/94. At present, there are only tests for file I/O system procedures. We also need to test other facilities that use file I/O, such as GFI, printing, and bitmaps. Interested parties are encouraged to add other tests.

g2:c.CHECK-BOX.g2:a.LABEL: begin tests when G2 is started
show stats at end of tests

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: pretend-to-read-memory-usage-meter(wait-please: truth-value) = (integer) begin return 0; end

g2:c.FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: jh, 1/3/96. Occasionally, this test encounters file timestamps that are off by a bit more than 1.0, but always less than 2.0. The explanation in the above 1/11/95 comment is insufficient to account for this problem. Although we have not yet diagnosed this problem, we will temporarily raise the tolerance in latest-date-file-was-accessed-test() so that we can ge a clean regression report for the forthcoming 5.0 beta. To track the investigation of this problem after the beta, see bug HQ-1103613, "File modification dates off occasionally".

jh, 1/11/95. File timestamps are stored as integers, while UNIX times are floats. So they can be off by as much as 1 second minus epsilon. That is why the comparisons in the latest-data-file-was-xxx tests have a fuzz of 1.0.

jh, 12/1/94. The g2-latest-date-file-was-xxx system procedures are not differentiated very well, at least on my Sun 4. They only update at the time a file was created, and don't reflect things like subsequent writes or renames. So the regression tests for these system procedures are wimpy, merely testing if the date is in the ballpark of time the file was opened.
jh, 12/1/94. The general policy is that every test is self-contained, e.g. test B cannot depend on test B either leaving a file around or cleaning up after itself.

jh, 11/29/94. Have to change the xxx-directory-to-access-for-automation text-parameters underneath example-directory-operations when the uilroot.kb inconsistency is cleared up and I move file-io.kb from "/bt/ab/src/kbs/" to "/bt/ab/src/tests/" where it belongs. Have to fix non-automounted-unix-default-directory-for-automation to hold the text "/bt/ab/dst/sparcsol/g2/test/" rather than the g2-latest or g2-opt text and get rid of deletable-development-default-directory-for-testing and deletable-and-readable-development-default-directory-for-testing when I am through testing.

jh, 11/29/94. Don't forget to surround every file I/O test with a leak test. jh, 11/30/94. Note that "allow scheduled drawing?" in drawing-parameters must be "yes" and you must call g2-work-on-drawing(true) at the end of each attempt to prevent false leak reports.

jh, 11/29/94. Note that the procedures for manual tests are of the form test-xxx(), while the procedures for automated tests are of the form xxx-test(). Since I want to expend the least possible effort in converting manual tests to automatic, this potential confusion will have to do for now.
